metadata.TITLE: Catch Up On The Latest News Clips - ITVX
metadata.DESC: Discover the latest and breaking news clips from ITV. ITVX - The UK's freshest streaming service.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: The latest ITV News headlines - as Hamas leader says group close to hostage deal with Israel
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: Watch a short summary of today's top stories from the ITV News team.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Hamas leader says group 'close to reaching a truce agreement' with Israel
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: Ismail Haniyeh has reportedly claimed that a deal with Israel is "approaching", which could involve the release of hostages.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Police locate car used by boys who went missing on camping trip in North Wales
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: The four teenagers were believed to be travelling in Snowdonia when they were reported missing on Sunday, triggering a major search effort.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Professor Chris Whitty says first Covid lockdown came 'a bit too late'
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: The government's Chief Medical Officer has been giving evidence to the Covid Inquiry, denying that he warned ministers against lockdown.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Covid inquiry: The key moments so far as Sir Chris Whitty gives evidence
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: Sir Chris became a household name during the pandemic as he provided public health and clinical advice to the Department of Health.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Police criticised for 'avoidable and unnecessary' release of Nicola Bulley's health details
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: An independent review has criticised Lancashire Constabulary for sharing information about the 45-year-old's health.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Bank of England chief warns inflation isn't beaten yet ahead of Autumn Statement
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: Ahead of expected tax cuts in the Autumn Statement, the Governor of the Bank of England has struck a cautious note on the economy.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Trapped tunnel workers seen on camera for first time since collapse
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: A second pipe reached the 41 construction workers on Tuesday. They have been trapped in the collapsed tunnel in northern India for nine days.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Doctors told to be on alert for measles following dramatic rise in cases
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: The Royal College of Pediatricians says doctors are 'living in fear' after a huge rise in the number of people contracting measles.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: King and Queen welcome South Korean President to Buckingham Palace
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: It's hoped the King and Queen can give a royal boost to a potential new trade deal between the UK and South Korea.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: The Rundown: ITV News' daily update for teenagers
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: Watch a new edition of The Rundown every afternoon.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Largely dry for many: Watch the latest ITV Weather
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: Watch the latest UK forecast from the ITV Weather team.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Watch the latest ITV Lunchtime News
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: Catch up with the latest from the ITV News team.

longformData.title: Good Morning Britain
longformData.description: BAFTA-nominated breakfast show covering the latest news, sport & weather

longformData.title: ITV News at Ten
longformData.description: The latest news from ITV News at Ten

longformData.title: ITV Evening News
longformData.description: All the latest news from the ITV Evening News team

longformData.title: ITV News: Live on ITVX
longformData.description: A moment of history, The State Opening of Parliament, King Charles' first as the monarch.

longformData.title: King Charles III: The Coronation
longformData.description: History in the making - relive the day in full

longformData.title: Tonight
longformData.description: Compelling current affairs stories that get to the heart of what matters

longformData.title: Peston
longformData.description: ITV News' Robert Peston presents his lively political interview programme

longformData.title: The Clinic
longformData.description: Timely documentary about the history of a controversial NHS unit

longformData.title: 60 Minutes: Prince Harry Interview
longformData.description: Prince Harry sits down with Anderson Cooper from CBS' 60 Minutes

longformData.title: Highlights
longformData.description: A moment in history - watch highlights from an unforgettable day

longformData.title: The King in Kenya
longformData.description: Follow King Charles’ state visit to Kenya in this special programme

longformData.title: The King's Speech - An ITV News Special
longformData.description: A moment of history, The State Opening of Parliament, King Charles' first as monarch.

longformData.title: Ukraine's Stolen Children
longformData.description: Compelling story of the children taken to Russia after war broke out

clips.episodeTitle: Covid inquiry: Leading adviser said that Johnson 'struggled' to grasp scientific concepts
clips.synopsis: The former Chief Scientific Adviser Sir Patrick Vallance said it was difficult to explain the implications of coronavirus to Boris Johnson.

clips.episodeTitle: Hunt reportedly weighing up plans to cut rate of income tax in Autumn Statement
clips.synopsis: The Chancellor has signalled he wants to 'lighten the tax burden' in his upcoming Autumn Statement on Wednesday.

clips.episodeTitle: Sunak says he will 'work night and day' to get Rwanda plans through
clips.synopsis: The Prime Minister insisted he will ensure courts cannot 'systemically' block flights to Rwanda and didn't rule out triggering an election over the policy.

clips.episodeTitle: Chancellor refuses to say whether those with long-term sickness will have benefits withdrawn
clips.synopsis: In an interview ITV News' Economics Editor Joel Hills, Jeremy Hunt laid out his plans to reduce the number of people out of work with health conditions.

clips.episodeTitle: MPs demand that new Rwanda legislation be exempt from human rights laws
clips.synopsis: ITV News understands that dozens of backbench Conservative MPs are demanding that new legislation be protected from legal challenges based on human rights laws.

clips.episodeTitle: Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer looking for party unity after major Gaza rebellion
clips.synopsis: Labour has sought to play down splits in the party after Sir Keir Starmer lost ten frontbenchers in a major rebellion over his stance on the war in Gaza.

clips.episodeTitle: What will 'emergency legislation' actually look like, and what if it doesn't work?
clips.synopsis: Our UK Editor Paul Brand dissects the government's Rwanda plan, what Rishi Sunak means by 'emergency legislation', and whether it will work.

clips.episodeTitle: Sunak announces 'emergency legislation' after Rwanda policy blocked by UK's top court
clips.synopsis: Rishi Sunak said the legislation will ensure Rwanda is deemed a safe country, allowing him to bypass what he called the 'merry-go-round' of court rulings.

clips.episodeTitle: Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer looking for party unity after major Gaza rebellion
clips.synopsis: Labour has sought to play down splits in the party after Sir Keir Starmer lost ten frontbenchers in a major rebellion over his stance on the war in Gaza.

clips.episodeTitle: Government's Rwanda migrant plan ruled unlawful by Supreme Court
clips.synopsis: The prime minister says he is prepared to change UK law and will sign a new deal with Rwanda, after the Supreme Court ruled his flagship asylum policy unlawful.

clips.episodeTitle: What will happen now the government's Rwanda plan has been ruled unlawful?
clips.synopsis: ITV News Political Editor Robert Peston considers what the fallout could be after the Supreme Court ruled the government's asylum policy unlawful.

clips.episodeTitle: 'You have repeatedly failed to deliver': Braverman sends Sunak scathing letter after sacking
clips.synopsis: In her resignation letter, the former Home Secretary told the Prime Minister his 'plan is not working' and claimed he has 'repeatedly failed to deliver'.

clips.episodeTitle: Braverman's stinging attack: Is Sunak in trouble, and do our ministers really hate each other?
clips.synopsis: Tom Bradby is joined by ITV News Political Editor Robert Peston and Deputy Political Editor Anushka Asthana to discuss Braverman's blistering attack on Sunak.

clips.episodeTitle: Irish-Israeli father of nine-year-old Hamas hostage pleads for her release
clips.synopsis: Tom Hand, who was initially told his daughter had been killed, says he is living his worst nightmare as he pleads for her safe return.

clips.episodeTitle: Reports suggest Israel and Hamas are close to a hostage release deal
clips.synopsis: Israel's ambassador to the U.S. said he's 'hopeful' of a deal 'in the coming days', as more than 30 babies were evacuated from the Al-Shifa hospital.

clips.episodeTitle: Dozens of people reportedly killed at United Nations-run school in northern Gaza
clips.synopsis: Witnesses say an Israeli airstrike hit the Fakhoura school. The UN agency that runs it said thousands were sheltering there, calling the incident 'horrifying'.

clips.episodeTitle: Fatima's story: A child's life forever changed by war in Gaza
clips.synopsis: Fatima lost her legs at the age of 14 months, as she was learning to use them. She and her mother were left homeless after Israeli shelling last month.

clips.episodeTitle: Cameron: We'll support Ukraine 'however long it takes' for victory
clips.synopsis: Speaking with President Zelenskyy, the new foreign secretary reitrerated the UK's ongoing support for Ukraine.

clips.episodeTitle: Israeli military claims its troops have entered Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City
clips.synopsis: Israel says the hospital is being used to conceal a Hamas military facility. Hamas rejects this. Medical staff have struggled to work with dwindling supplies.

clips.episodeTitle: Huge cracks in roads as looming Iceland volcano eruption prompts mass evacuation
clips.synopsis: A volcano in Iceland may be about to erupt, with 900 mini earthquakes and huge cracks in the ground signaling an impending explosion and prompting evacuations.

clips.episodeTitle: Warning that lives of premature babies at risk at Gaza's main hospital
clips.synopsis: The World Health Organisation says Al-Shifa hospital is no longer functioning, after it ran out of fuel as the Israeli bombardment of Gaza continues.

clips.episodeTitle: At least 40 workers trapped after tunnel collapse in northern India
clips.synopsis: Rescue missions are underway to save the trapped workers, although officials say that it could take 'some time to bring them out'.

clips.episodeTitle: Second major hospital in Gaza 'runs out of fuel' as fighting intensifies nearby
clips.synopsis: Israel's Prime Minister has dismissed calls for a ceasefire as the WHO says it has grave concerns about the safety of hospital staff and patients.

clips.episodeTitle: Thousands evacuated in Iceland as the country prepares for a volcanic eruption
clips.synopsis: Authorities ordered thousands of people living in the southwestern town of Grindavík to evacuate as a precaution as concerns over a volcanic eruption grow..

clips.episodeTitle: Lion on the loose near Rome caught after prowling the streets for hours
clips.synopsis: The animal had escaped from the circus and was filmed walking through the empty streets of seaside town Ladispoli, with residents warned to stay home.

clips.episodeTitle: Gaza's main hospital without power as doctors warn patients are dying
clips.synopsis: Israel has accused Hamas of operating from tunnels underneath the al-Shifa hospital, but staff and Hamas have denied this claim.

clips.episodeTitle: Doctors warn of dangerous impact of measles as cases spike and vaccine uptake slumps
clips.synopsis: Public health officials have told ITV News every region in England has reported an infection, which could lead to fatal consequences.

clips.episodeTitle: New coming of age film explores themes of consent and sex
clips.synopsis: 'How to Have Sex' director Molly Manning Walker says she hopes her film will help students discuss issues around consent openly.

clips.episodeTitle: Firefighters suffered racism that drove them to take their own lives, families tell ITV News
clips.synopsis: Relatives of firefighters who they say lost their lives to racism have told our UK Editor Paul Brand they want urgent change within the service.

clips.episodeTitle: Young lives cut short in Gaza's 'graveyard for children' as over 5,000 feared dead
clips.synopsis: ITV News hears stories of loss and fear from the Gaza Strip, where over 5,000 children are feared to have died since the onset of the conflict in the region.

clips.episodeTitle: 'No fault evictions' rise by 38% in a year as government delays court order ban
clips.synopsis: ITV News meets victims of what's known as a "Section 21 notice", a court order which is used by landlords in England to evict their tenants with no explanation.

clips.episodeTitle: ITV News enters Gaza for first time and witnesses devastation from weeks of bombing
clips.synopsis: The team was escorted into the town of Beit Hanoun in northern Gaza by Israeli forces, who supervised what they were allowed to film and to show.

clips.episodeTitle: Whistleblowing: Are NHS doctors being listened to when they raise concerns?
clips.synopsis: A survey, carried out for ITV by the hospital doctors' union HCSA, found more than 70% think it would damage their careers to speak up about patient safety.

clips.episodeTitle: The groundbreaking cancer trial using herpes as a vaccine to treat tumours
clips.synopsis: By injecting an altered version of the herpes virus directly into cancerous areas, doctors hope to attack the tumours and trigger the body's immune system.

clips.episodeTitle: Campaigners call for more to be done to overturn Post Office prosecutions
clips.synopsis: Its thought that hundreds of innocent Post Office workers were prosecuted as part of the 'Horizon' scandal.

clips.episodeTitle: Mothers left 'heartbroken' as their children face lengthy waits to fix tongue-ties
clips.synopsis: Fixing a baby's tongue-tie can be a relatively quick and simple procedure, but waiting times can vary hugely across the country - up to more than twenty weeks.

clips.episodeTitle: Rapid rise in demand for temporary accommodation creating new housing crisis
clips.synopsis: A record 104,000 households in England are currently in temporary accommodation, with many living in fear of having nowhere to go and sleeping on the street.

clips.episodeTitle: Will the Isle of Man become the first place in the British Isles to legalise assisted dying?
clips.synopsis: Lawmakers are voting this week on whether to approve the practice, but there are fears the island could become a destination for 'death tourism'.

clips.episodeTitle: British Jews 'more fearful than any time since 1945', Chief Rabbi tells ITV News
clips.synopsis: Rabbi Ephraim Mirvis said the recent rise in antisemitic hate crimes was causing "deep pain" for Jewish communities in the UK.

clips.episodeTitle: What could the Chancellor announce in his autumn statement?
clips.synopsis: The Chancellor Jeremy Hunt is gearing up for a crucial autumn statement on Wednesday - and it looks like some tax cuts may be in the offing.

clips.episodeTitle: Parcel firms delivering a 'miserable' service to customers, say Citizens Advice
clips.synopsis: Find out where the country's major delivery firms rank in the Citizens Advice league table.

clips.episodeTitle: Breakthrough gene therapy offers hope for people with two blood disorders
clips.synopsis: The treatment could be used for people with sickle cell disease and beta thalassemia. It works by correcting a genetic error relating to red blood cells.

clips.episodeTitle: Is Rishi Sunak on track to meet his five pledges to the public?
clips.synopsis: Back in January, the Prime Minister made five key promises to voters which he said people should judge him on. So what progress has he made on them?

clips.episodeTitle: The extraordinary amounts of sugar in coffee shop treats - and who the worst offenders are
clips.synopsis: Action on Sugar has found more than a third of treats sold in major high street coffee shops exceed an adult's daily guideline limit of sugar in one go.

clips.episodeTitle: Supreme Court to determine the fate of the government's Rwanda migrant plan
clips.synopsis: On Wednesday, the UK's highest court will give its ruling on whether the government's plan to send some of those arriving on small boats to Rwanda can go ahead.

clips.episodeTitle: Home Secretary Suella Braverman's most controversial moments
clips.synopsis: After causing yet another row with her article about 'bias' in the policing of protests, we look at some of the Home Secretary's most controversial moments.

clips.episodeTitle: How will children be protected online under new laws?
clips.synopsis: New regulations put forward by Ofcom will require the biggest social media sites to protect children from online groomers.

clips.episodeTitle: Can a protest legally be banned?
clips.synopsis: The police have faced political pressure to stop a pro-Palestinian march in London on Armistice Day, but what action can they actually take?

clips.episodeTitle: British women are biggest binge drinkers in the world - but how bad is the problem?
clips.synopsis: Binge drinking is defined as having at least six drinks in one sitting - which 26% of British women do at least once a month.

clips.episodeTitle: What is Hezbollah? The militant group in Lebanon explained
clips.synopsis: There are real fears Hezbollah could enter the war, leading to the conflict spreading throughout the region. But who is it run by and what are their aims?

clips.episodeTitle: How did the Covid pandemic affect the brain?
clips.synopsis: A new study suggests that the pandemic sped up cognitive decline in those aged over 50, irrespective of whether they actually contracted the virus.

clips.episodeTitle: As more people turn to Buy Now Pay Later, what do you need to know?
clips.synopsis: There are growing concerns that the increase in use of Buy Now Pay Later schemes is leading to dangerous buying habits for some who can't afford it.

clips.episodeTitle: Mayor blocks move to build huge Vegas-style Sphere in London - but are plans completely deflated?
clips.synopsis: The Mayor of London said the LED light-filled venue would have a negative impact on local residents which outweighed potential economic benefits.

clips.episodeTitle: What's next for the 17-year-old named Britain's top female surfer?
clips.synopsis: A 17-year-old from Newquay has been named Britain's top female surfer and is looking ahead to competing at the Olympics while studying for her A Levels

clips.episodeTitle: Last chance to see UK's only giant pandas before they leave Edinburgh Zoo
clips.synopsis: Tian Tian and Yang Guang will return to China in December after 12 years in Scotland, leaving visitors only two weeks to see them.

clips.episodeTitle: Celebrating the legacy of Windrush and breaking down barriers through jewellery
clips.synopsis: Norma Banton's was the first black woman to open a shop in the heart of Birmingham's jewellry quarter, where she's working to keep her parent's legacy alive.

clips.episodeTitle: The million pound plan to save the UK's Pine Martens
clips.synopsis: Pine Martens have become virtually extinct in England, but new plans in Northumberland hope to restore their habitats.

clips.episodeTitle: Supermarket chain Booths ditches self-checkouts in customer service drive
clips.synopsis: Supermarket chain Booths is scrapping 'problematic' and 'unreliable' self-service checkouts in an effort to 'double down' on its customer service standards.

clips.episodeTitle: Music icon Sting receives Freedom of the Borough of North Tyneside
clips.synopsis: Multi-award-winning musician Sting has received the Freedom of the Borough of North Tyneside, the highest honour any local authority can bestow.

clips.episodeTitle: Shear brilliance: How Welsh wool could help prevent peat bogs from drying out
clips.synopsis: A new trial is underway in the Brecon Beacons, using thick fleeces of Welsh sheep to stem the erosive flow of water of vital peat bogs.

clips.episodeTitle: Thousands of baby lobsters released into the sea in a bid to save the North East's fishing industry
clips.synopsis: Whitby's status as one of the largest lobster-catching ports in Europe has been under threat due to declining fishing stocks.

clips.episodeTitle: Young girl meets the stem donor who saved her life
clips.synopsis: Sofia Gardella was diagnosed with a rare blood disorder aged two. In 2015 Sofia was matched with a woman from Germany, whose stem cells saved her life.

clips.episodeTitle: Military veterans who took part in nuclear testing awarded medals
clips.synopsis: Two military veterans who were used as "guinea pigs" during the testing of nuclear bombs have been awarded medals recognising their service after over 60 years.

clips.episodeTitle: Scotland's place in the space race: An exclusive look inside a Glasgow rocket making factory
clips.synopsis: The Space industry in Scotland is taking off with more satellites being built in Glasgow than anywhere else outside of Silicone Valley.

clips.episodeTitle: Artist pulps The Da Vinci Code books into £495 editions of George Orwell's 1984
clips.synopsis: After a charity shop was inundated with copies of The Da Vinci Code, David Shrigley decided to pulp thousands of books for his latest project and for charity.
